If notability cannot be shown, the article is likely to be merged, redirected, or deleted. *Find sources:* "Belimau" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(April 2016)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* The **Belimau** bath is a [Malay Indonesian](/wiki/Malay_Indonesians) tradition, observed in order to welcome the month of [Ramadan](/wiki/Ramadan), especially in [Bangka Belitung](/wiki/Bangka_Belitung) and [Riau](/wiki/Riau) provinces. The tradition has been carried down for generations among the [Minangkabau people](/wiki/Minangkabau_people) before Islam arrived in Indonesia, as they were praciticing [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia), whereby this ceremony could have been inspired by [Makara Sankranti](/wiki/Makar_Sankranti). Belimau consists of washing or bathing for physical and spiritual purification using [limau](/wiki/Calamansi) water. In the Pacific Islands, the Belimau tradition ended about 300 years ago, but it was revived around 2006. Since then, local governments have promoted the Belimau bath tradition as a part of [religious tourism](/wiki/Religious_tourism). The Belimau Bath ceremony is held once a year, one week before Ramadan. - Ramadan in Indonesia - [Islam in Indonesia](/wiki/Islam_in_Indonesia) This [Islam-related](/wiki/Islam) article is a stub.
